title: Health supplements | why you need to top up with Vitamin D
text: Thinking that your diet gives you everything you need is a bit of a myth. While we assume that we can get all our nutrients from food, its nutritional content depends on factors such as how long vegetables and fruit have been sitting on supermarket shelves; how long we keep food in our fridge; and how we cook it. Not only that, we all lead busy lives. As a young mother battling with sleepless nights and a 16-month-old child while running my own business, I know how it feels to be exhausted. Think of vitamin supplements as a top-up rather than a food replacement. Taking an all-round multivitamin daily can help to make up where we may be falling short. I take a Solgar Multiplus with Energy Essentials tablet each day. Iodine will be the next big issue in nutrition, because there has been a general decline in milk consumption, particularly among women The hot topic right now is Vitamin D deficiency, because most of us do not get enough sunlight. One in five Britons may now be deficient in vitamin D, according to NHS guidance, and the problem will get worse in the autumn. Young women and teenagers are also not getting enough iron, because of misconceptions about red meat. People think that you can get all the iron you need from spinach, but that’s not true. Sorry Popeye. Iodine will be the next big issue in nutrition, because there has been a general decline in milk consumption, particularly among women. Up to two in three British girls and women are thought to have low iodine levels.
